content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (<math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mn>12</mn></math> points, suggested time <math alttext="25" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn></math> minutes) A sample of a monatomic ideal gas is confined in a cylinder with a movable piston. The piston is free to move, and there is negligible friction between the piston and the cylinder. The graph shows the pressure <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math> as a function of the volume <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll"><mi>V</mi></math>. In Process <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the gas initially in State <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is compressed until it reaches State <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, as shown in the graph. (a) i. According to the graph, how does the internal energy <math alttext="U sub B" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> of the gas in State <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> compare to the internal energy <math alttext="U sub A" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> of the gas in State <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>? Explain your reasoning.

frqParts.text: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (<math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mn>12</mn></math> points, suggested time <math alttext="25" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn></math> minutes) A sample of a monatomic ideal gas is confined in a cylinder with a movable piston. The piston is free to move, and there is negligible friction between the piston and the cylinder. The graph shows the pressure <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math> as a function of the volume <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll"><mi>V</mi></math>. In Process <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the gas initially in State <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is compressed until it reaches State <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, as shown in the graph. (a) i. According to the graph, how does the internal energy <math alttext="U sub B" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> of the gas in State <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> compare to the internal energy <math alttext="U sub A" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> of the gas in State <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>? Explain your reasoning.

ii. Derive a general equation for the change in the internal energy <math alttext="delta U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Î”</mi><mi>U</mi></math> of an ideal gas that is taken through a thermodynamic process. Express your answer in terms of the initial and final state variables: initial pressure <math alttext="P sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>, initial volume <math alttext="V sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>, final pressure <math alttext="P sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>, final volume <math alttext="V sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>, and fundamental constants as appropriate.
(b) Indicate whether your equation for part (a)(ii) is consistent with your answer from part (a)(i). Briefly justify your answer.

(c) When the gas is still in State <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, the cylinder is placed in a water bath at the same temperature as the gas. In Process <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, a student allows the gas to slowly expand at a constant temperature until the gas returns to State <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>. Sketch Process <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> on the graph above.

(d) How does the magnitude of the work <math alttext="W sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> done on the gas in Process <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> described in part (a) compare to the magnitude of the work <math alttext="W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> done on the gas during isothermal Process <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> described in part (c)?___ <math alttext="W sub 1 is greater than W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> ___ <math alttext="W sub 1 equals W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> ___ <math alttext="W sub 1 is less than W sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>Briefly justify your answer.

In another experiment, samples of two different monatomic gases <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> are placed inside a chamber. The chamber is cylindrical and insulated, and the samples of Gas <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and Gas <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> are initially separated by a barrier, as shown above. The temperature of the samples is the same, but the number of moles of Gas <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is greater than the number of moles of Gas <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>. (e) <math alttext="F sub A" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> is the force exerted by the sample of Gas <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> on the barrier, and <math alttext="F sub B" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> is the force exerted by the sample of Gas <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> on the barrier. Compare the magnitudes of <math alttext="F sub A" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="F sub B" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math>. Briefly explain your reasoning using macroscopic physics principles.

(f) The barrier is quickly removed from the chamber, allowing the two gases to mix. On average, when an atom of Gas <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> collides with an atom of Gas <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, is energy transferred from the Gas <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> atom to the Gas <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> atom, from the Gas <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> atom to the Gas <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> atom, or neither? Briefly explain your answer.

topic.text: 9.1: Kinetic Theory of Temperature and Pressure

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
